Award.AwardTitle: BECS: Collaborative Research: Dynamical Networks and Collective Synchronization of Coupled Lasers
Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to conduct rigorous mathematical analysis of complex networks of interconnected dynamical systems, and apply the developed methods to control and collectively synchronize arrays of coupled semiconductor lasers. The main idea is based on the dynamical, rather than traditional static, description of the topology of a network, which allows to account for an analysis and evaluation of cumulative action of all three major ingredients that form a dynamical network: 1. local dynamics of elements of the network, 2. interactions between the elements of a network, 3. topology of the network. The project seeks an integration of the mathematical foundations with real world applications, and the developed mathematical machinery will be used to find synchronization conditions and to choose control parameters for synchronization of arrays of coupled semiconductor lasers.

The project will advance the fields of complex dynamical networks, nonlinear dynamics, and coupled semiconductor lasers, and provide theoretical guidance for laser experiments that may lead to significant technological impact in applications of semiconductor lasers such as space, fiber, and underwater communication, welding, cutting and others. The project integrates research projects with education activities through undergraduate and graduate education and research training, short course and workshop development, and outreach to K-12 education. The team also plans to recruit women engineering students and to retain them into careers in science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Collective behaviors have long been observed in naturally occurring systems, e.g., flocks of birds, clusters of biological organisms, and gene networks. With the remarkable advances in networking technologies, a wide range of man-made systems have displayed cooperative behaviors, e.g., large power systems, transportation networks, and distributed sensor components communicating across high-speed data networks. Although useful cooperative behaviors have been established, fundamental mechanisms forming such behaviors and the principles that will allow more sophisticated and robust distributed systems have yet to be developed.

In this research, a team of multidisciplinary faculty from Mathematics, Physics, and Engineering studied general rigorous mathematical approach to the analysis of evolution of complex networks of interconnected dynamical systems with any graph of interactions (topology of a network), and applied the developed method to control coupled semiconductor laser systems for collective synchronization. The main idea is based on the dynamical, rather than traditional static, description of the topology of a network. Therefore, it allowed us to account for an analysis and evaluation of cumulative action of all three major ingredients which form a dynamical network: (a) (local) dynamics of elements of the network (which can be different for different elements), (b) interactions between the elements of a network, and (c) topology of the network.

Arrays of semiconductor lasers is a very important experimental systems where one can explicitly experimentally observe and alter the dynamics of each separate element in the array, therefore a fair comparison between the mathematical results and experimental observations can be implemented. For this reason, arrays of lasers are very widely studied by scientists in the field of nonlinear dynamics. Also, ability to synchronize large arrays of lasers provides a significant benefit since the resulting power density (power per unit area) scales as the square of the number of lasers in array (for non-synchronized lasers power density scales as the number of lasers in array). Ability to concentrate very large power on a very small area is important for wide variety of applications. Synchronization patterns of linear identical nearest neighbor and globally coupled laser arrays have been extensively studied. In our research we applied rigorous mathematical results to networks of nonlinear oscillators and lasers, where laser coupling was neither nearest neighbor nor global, and laser coupling constants as well as other parameters were non-identical.

The performed research advanced our understanding of complex dynamical networks and the state of the art in coupled semiconductor lasers. The specific outcomes included 1) rigorous mathematical theorems for interconnected complex dynamical systems with arbitrary topology of a network, 2) conditions on network topology and coupling strength for synchronization of coupled semiconductor lasers, and 3) theoretical guidance on how to choose control parameters for synchronization. Our results provided sound theoretical guidance for laser array synchronization experiments. Some of analytical and computational predictions for laser coupling topology were experimentally tested and resulted in excellent synchronization of coupled laser diodes.
